awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multi-Level Occupancy Intervention, Simulation and Education for Energy Reduction in Existing Buildings
awd_abstract_narration:
1349921 (Menassa).  

Despite significant advances in technology, existing buildings are still the highest consumers of energy and emitters of harmful greenhouse gases. While it is argued that education and information sharing are appropriate occupancy intervention strategies for energy reduction, no empirical research has been done to understand (1) how different building occupants respond to intervention strategies, (2) what occupancy characteristics influence this response, (3) how to supplement education with other strategies to achieve long term energy reduction, and (4) how simulation can be used to develop a functional and educational environment for building stakeholders. The goal of this CAREER grant is to address this gap in research and education to achieve a fundamental understanding of what occupancy characteristics and social relationships play a key mediation role to induce significant energy use reduction in buildings. The investigator will perform basic research, design appropriate tools, and develop educational materials to enable effective implementation of energy reduction intervention strategies at the occupancy level in buildings. This research is targeted to result in fundamental contributions to understand the mediation role that building occupancy MOA (Motivation, Opportunity and Ability) and SNT (Social Network Topology) play in determining the effectiveness of intervention strategies. This is to be achieved through a scientific approach to quantitatively measure the occupancy MOA and SNT. Additional important targeted contributions of this project are to identify the key fundamental differences among various energy intervention strategies aimed at building occupants, and to establish a correlation between the effectiveness of these strategies and specific building clusters. This would significantly reduce time and effort required to choose and implement energy intervention strategies in buildings by providing a fundamental scientific understanding of what intervention strategies can be applied for given occupancy MOA and SNT characteristics. Finally, the proposed research targets to develop, test and validate a model that allows decision makers to understand how reducing energy in their buildings is influenced by the buildings? occupancy MOA levels, SNT and proper selection of intervention strategies. This approach to understanding and modeling the mediation role that occupancy MOA and SNT play in processing information included in intervention strategies aims to result in effective, economical and sustainable approaches to reduce energy use in buildings. The dissemination of the project results through different media will seek to have a significant impact of educating decision makers about which intervention strategies to choose to achieve long term and effective energy reduction in their building. As part of this project, the investigator will leverage existing resources at the University of Michigan to achieve full integration of her research and educational activities. These resources include: (1) The Center for Research on Learning and Teaching in Engineering (CRLT-Engineering), (2) the NSF-funded Michigan Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (MI-LSAMP),  (3) the Office of Engineering Outreach and Engagement (OEOE) and Marian Sarah Parker Scholars (MSP) Program, and (4) the Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program (UROP). The latter three collaborations will allow the investigator to mentor underrepresented minorities in STEM disciplines, with them potentially moving on to pursue graduate degrees. Beyond traditional education, the results of this research will be disseminated through online course offerings to practicing professionals.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this CAREER proposal is to develop an understanding of what occupancy characteristics and social relationships play a key mediation role to induce energy use reduction in buildings through occupancy focused intervention strategies. The main research and education activities are summarized below:

Developed an Integrated Motivation-Opportunity-Ability (MOA) Framework to Achieve Large Scale Energy Savings in Buildings: Occupant behavior has a significant impact on building energy consumption. To reduce energy use in office buildings, various intervention strategies have been investigated to promote energy-saving behaviors among occupants. The main research question was: what are the determinants of energy-saving behaviors in the organizational context? To address the identified research question, this study proposes an integrated framework to identify the important factors influencing energy-saving behaviors in the workplace. An online survey is distributed to collect data from multiple office buildings across the US for a total of 1,200 responses. Results show that opportunity has the strongest effect on energy-saving behaviors, followed by motivation and ability. The demonstrated role of opportunity suggests that interventions for energy conservation in offices can primarily focus on creating a favorable organizational and interpersonal environment which supports energy-saving behaviors. Ability showed a weak effect on behaviors. This is due to the type of behaviors considered: saving energy in offices requires no knowledge beyond common sense (e.g., knowing standby equipment still consumes electricity is sufficient for employees to reduce the plug load) and requires little effort to perform (e.g., unplugging the monitor is an easy task).

Developed a Lightweight and adaptive building simulation (LABS) framework for integrated building energy and thermal comfort analysis: This study developed the LABS framework that capitalizes on Lightweight Communications and Marshalling (LCM), an inter-process communication framework widely used by the robotics community. The objective of this framework is to develop a coupled and distributed simulation environment that helps in understanding the complexity arising from the combined effects of interdependent building systems (including occupant behavior), by connecting and exchanging information across several software programs and data streams.

Implement LABS to Realize Net Zero Building Energy Retrofits based on Occupant Behavior and Building Material Performance: it is important to find effective strategies to retrofit existing buildings to NZEB, as most buildings in the United States stock are old and need suitable refurbishment. Furthermore, it is necessary to track the performance of the installed retrofit measures over the extended service life of a building to make sure that net-zero energy level is maintained for the remaining serviceable life of the building’s under any occupancy scenario. Current energy simulation tools do not analyze the building’s lifecycle dynamic behavior by investigating and understanding the various interdependencies (e.g., the impact of material degradation on the efficiency of retrofit measures, changes in occupant behavior). This study used LABS to model and analyze the life cycle energy use in a building by incorporating the various dynamic events over the life of a building, thereby providing the opportunity to devise efficient strategies for retrofitting and maintaining the analyzed buildings as NZEBs. Through a case study example, it is shown that effectiveness of energy efficiency measures (EEMs) varies across several representative locations in the US. EEMs (modifying the wall insulation and the windows glazing material) work better for the large buildings. For locations with acute cold climate, the selected EEMs works better, when compared to the locations hot weather. 

Robotic Data Collection and Simulation Approach for Collecting Occupancy and Building Performance Data: This work introduces a novel concept of using autonomous mobile indoor robots for gathering critical actionable building and occupancy information in real-time, and discusses how this information can be further utilized for various analyses and critical decision-making including building retrofit analysis and occupancy interventions. The approach develops the navigation and drift correction algorithms developed for autonomous robot operation. A case study is performed to evaluate the functional equivalency of using a multi-sensor robot to collect high-fidelity information compared with traditional pre-installed/fixed sensor networks. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility and applicability of the proposed method in large areas using only a sparse set of sensors mounted on mobile indoor robots. Additionally, one more case study was performed to show how the data collected by the robot can be utilized in making informed retrofit decisions. 

Educational and Mentoring Contributions: This project offered several students opportunities to work in different research aspects. Most of the students who contributed to the project, were able to publish and present their work at highly visible venues in this field. In addition, the findings of this work have been incorporated into two classes that the PI taught at the undergraduate level and graduate level. The results of the research were also presented to industry and academia at several venues. The results of this project have also been presented to both practitioners and academicians in the US and internationally.
